sen.j: 多宝塔（たほうとう）は、寺院建築のうち仏塔における形式のひとつである。
sen.e: Tahoto (literally, "multi-treasure pagoda") represent an architecture of pagodas, religious buildings in Asia.
Tahoto (literally, "multiple-treasure pagoda") represent an architecture of pagodas, which are religious buildings in Asia.
Tahoto (literally, "multiple-treasure pagoda") represent an architecture of pagodas, which are religious buildings in Asia.

sen.j: 現代の寺院建築用語・文化財用語としては、一般に裳階付き単層塔である。
sen.e: Today's temple architects and cultural property experts define tahoto as a single-level tower with a Mokoshi (pent roof).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （１）ここで、「単層塔」という表現が使われているのが理解できません。下記の記述からも、少なくとも二層以上はあるように思うのですが。。。原文どおりに訳しておきます。
sen.e: Today's temple architects and cultural property experts define tahoto as a single-level tower with a Mokoshi (pent roof).
Today's temple architects and cultural property experts define tahoto as a single-level tower with a Mokoshi (pent roof).

sen.j: 裳階平面が方形、中央部平面が円形のものを指す（例外あり）。
sen.e: If seen from the above, the mokoshi is square and the pagoda is round in the middle (although there are some exceptions).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （２）
sen.e: As viewed from above, the mokoshi is square and the pagoda is circular in the middle (although there are some exceptions).
As viewed from above, the mokoshi is square and the pagoda is circular in the middle (although there are some exceptions).

sen.j: なお、宝塔という呼称もあるが、現代の寺院建築用語・文化財用語では円筒形の塔身に方形の屋根を架けたものを「宝塔」と称している。
sen.e: Additionally, the term "hoto" is used by professionals to mention cylinder-shaped pagodas topped by square roofs.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （１）ここでは、「現代の寺院建築用語・文化財用語では」という表記が用いられていますが、上記に同様の表現があり、その際、用語として訳さず、現代の寺院建築家や文化財専門家に置き換えて訳しましたので、それを受けての訳として、同じ、長めの言葉の繰り返しを避け、「by professionals」という表現を使いました。元の日本語から少し離れてしまっていますが、前の流れからいうと返ってこのほうが読みやすくなっていると思われます。
sen.e: Additionally, the term "hoto" is used by professionals in reference to cylinder-shaped pagodas topped by squared roofs.
Additionally, the term 'hoto' is used by professionals in reference to cylinder-shaped pagodas topped by squared roofs.

sen.j: 形式上多宝塔とは区別されている。
sen.e: Thus, "hoto" are different from "tahoto" in style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （２）
sen.e: Thus, "hoto" are stylistically different from "tahoto."
Thus, hoto are stylistically different from tahoto.

tit.e: Where the tahoto is first cited
Where the tahoto is first cited
Where the tahoto is first cited

sen.j: 多宝塔は、「法華経」見宝塔品第十一に出てくる。
sen.e: The tahoto is mentioned in Chapter 11 of "Hokkekyo" (the Lotus Sutra), "Kenhotohon" (literally, "Seeing the Buddha nature").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）文言の説明自体が長く、ややこしいので、文を細かく分けました。「法華経」見宝塔品第十一について、「見宝塔品第十一」のうち、「品」は、章に近いもので、「見宝塔」章が、第十一番目の章になっています。（「見宝塔章」の中の、第十一段があるのではありません。）
sen.e: The tahoto is mentioned in Chapter 11 of "Hokkekyo" (the Lotus Sutra), "Kenhotohon" (literally, "Seeing the Buddha nature").
The tahoto is mentioned in Chapter 11 of 'Hokkekyo' (the Lotus Sutra), Kenhotohon (literally, 'Seeing the Buddha nature').

sen.j: 釈迦が法華経を説法していると多宝塔が現れたという。
sen.e: According to it, a tahoto appeared while Shakyamuni was preaching Hokekyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: According to it, a tahoto appeared while Shakyamuni was preaching Hokekyo.
According to it, a tahoto appeared while Shakyamuni was preaching Hokekyo.

sen.j: その中にいた多宝如来が半座を開け、釈迦に座を譲ったとされることに由来する。
sen.e: Then, Taho Nyorai (Prabhuta-ratnam), who was in there, turned over his position to Shakyamuni by giving him a half of his seat; this is how a tahoto has come into existence.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （3）
sen.e: Then, Taho Nyorai (Prabhuta-ratnam), who was inside, turned over his position to Shakyamuni by giving him half of his seat; this is how the tahoto came into existence.
Then, Taho Nyorai (Prabhuta-ratnam), who was inside, turned over his position to Shakyamuni by giving him half of his seat; this is how the tahoto came into existence.

sen.j: 見宝塔品には、「世尊（釈迦）が説法をしていると、大地から巨大な七宝塔（金、銀、瑠璃などの七宝で造られた塔）が涌出（ゆじゅつ）し、空中にそびえた」との説話がある。
sen.e: "Kenhotohon" says that while Seson (Shaka) was preaching, a huge Shippto (pagoda made of seven treasures, including gold, silver, and lazuli) gushed out of the ground and rose up high in the air.

"Kenhotohon" states that while Seson (Shaka) was preaching, a huge Shippto (pagoda made of seven treasures, including gold, silver and lapis lazuli) gushed out of the ground and rose high into the air.

Kenhotohon states that 'while Seson (Shaka) was preaching, a huge Shippoto (pagoda made of seven treasures, including gold, silver and lapis lazuli) gushed out of the ground and rose high into the air.'

sen.j: この宝塔は過去仏である多宝如来の塔であった。
sen.e: The pagoda was owned by Taho Nyorai, a "Kakobutsu" (Buddha before Shakyamuni).
The pagoda was owned by Taho Nyorai, a "Kakobutsu" (Buddha before Shakyamuni).
The pagoda was owned by Taho Nyorai, a Kakobutsu (Buddha before Shakyamuni).

sen.j: 塔内にいた多宝如来は釈迦の説く法華経の教えを讃嘆し、半座を開け、釈迦とともに並んで座ったと説かれる。
sen.e: Taho Nyorai, who had resided in the pagoda, was so impressed with Shaka's teachings that he gave a half of his seat to him and sat together with him.
Taho Nyorai, who was residing in the pagoda, was so impressed with Shaka's teachings that he gave half of his seat to him and sat together with him.
Taho Nyorai, who was residing in the pagoda, was so impressed with Shaka's teachings that he gave half of his seat to him and sat together with him.

sen.j: 「多宝塔」の名称はこの法華経の所説に由来するものと思われる。
sen.e: The name, "Tahoto" is considered to have derived from this chapter of Hokkekyo.
The name "Tahoto" is considered to have been derived from this chapter of Hokkekyo.
The name 'Tahoto' is considered to have been derived from this chapter of Hokkekyo.

sen.j: ただし、漢訳経文中の用語は「宝塔」または「七宝塔」となっている。
sen.e: In the Chinese version, however, the same pagoda is cited as "hoto" or "shippoto".
In the Chinese version, however, the same pagoda is cited as "hoto" or "shippoto."
In the Chinese version, however, the same pagoda is cited as 'hoto' or 'shippoto.'

sen.j: この見宝塔品のエピソードは法華経の中でもドラマチックな場面の1つであり、法華経の真実性を証明するものとして著名である。
sen.e: This episode makes one of the most dramatic scenes in Hokkekyo and is well known as a proof to validate it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）
sen.e: This episode makes one of the most dramatic scenes in Hokkekyo and is well known as proof and validation.
This episode makes one of the most dramatic scenes in Hokkekyo and is well known as proof and validation.

sen.j: さまざまな形式で造形化されている。
sen.e: The theme has been taken up in various forms of art.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: The theme has been taken up in various works of art.
The theme has been taken up in various works of art.

sen.j: たとえば、奈良県長谷寺所蔵の銅板法華説相図（国宝）である。
sen.e: An example of this is "Bronze Plaque Hokke-Sesso-Zu" (literally, "a picture of Buddha preaching Hokkekyo engraved on a bronze plaque") (a national treasure) possessed by Hasedera Temple in Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）
sen.e: An example of this is "Bronze Plaque Hokke-Sesso-Zu" (literally, "a picture of Buddha preaching Hokkekyo engraved on a bronze plaque") (a national treasure), possessed by Hasedera Temple in Nara Prefecture.

An example of this is Bronze Plaque Hokke-Sesso-Zu (literally, "a picture of Buddha preaching Hokkekyo engraved on a bronze plaque") (a national treasure), possessed by Hase-dera Temple in Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: この見宝塔品の場面を造形化したもので７世紀末の作品である。
sen.e: The work was created in the late seventh century by depicting the scene from Kenhotohon.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: The work, which was created in the late seventh century, depicts the scene from Kenhotohon.
The work, which was created in the late seventh century, depicts the scene from Kenhotohon.

sen.j: ただし、この作品に表されている塔は平面六角形の三層塔である。
sen.e: However, the pagoda in this work is a three-story tower with the floors in a hexagonal shape.
However, the pagoda in this work is a three-story tower with the floors in a hexagonal shape.
However, the pagoda in this work is a three-story tower with the floors in a hexagonal shape.

sen.j: 「法華経」見宝塔品第十一自体には、多宝塔（宝塔）の形式は記載されていない。
sen.e: "Kenhotohon", Chapter 11 of Hokkekyo, itself does not mention in what shape the tahoto was.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）分けなくても意味はわかると思われましたが、長々とつなげないほうが良いと思われましたので、分けました。
sen.e: "Kenhotohon," Chapter 11 of Hokkekyo, doesn't specifically indicate what shape the tahoto had.
Kenhotohon, Chapter 11 of Hokkekyo, doesn't specifically indicate what shape the tahoto had.

sen.j: 現在日本で見られるような多宝塔（宝塔）の形式については、日本独自のものといわれている。
sen.e: Tahoto now seen in Japan are considered to have developed uniquely in Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: The tahoto now seen in Japan are considered to have developed in a manner unique to the country.
The tahoto now seen in Japan are considered to have developed in a manner unique to the country.

sen.j: 中国や古代日本で多宝如来・釈迦如来を安置する塔には五重や三重の塔があったと考えられている。
sen.e: Scholars think that in China and ancient Japan, people built three-story or five-story pagodas and enshrined Taho Nyorai and Shaka Nyorai in them.
Scholars believe that in China, as well as in ancient Japan, people built three-story or five-story pagodas and enshrined Taho Nyorai and Shaka Nyorai in them.
Scholars believe that in China, as well as in ancient Japan, people built three-story or five-story pagodas and enshrined Taho Nyorai and Shaka Nyorai in them.

sen.j: 現代の寺院建築用語では初重平面が方形、二重平面が円形の二層塔を多宝塔と称する。
sen.e: Using current temple architecture terms, tahoto can be defined as a two-story tower with the first floor in a square shape and the second floor in a round shape.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）
sen.e: Using the current terms of temple architecture, a tahoto can be defined as a two-story tower with the first floor in a square shape and the second floor in a circular shape.
Using the current terms of temple architecture, a tahoto can be defined as a two-story tower with the first floor in a square shape and the second floor in a circular shape.

sen.j: さらに狭義には初重が方三間（1辺に柱が4本立ち柱間が4間あるの意）のものを多宝塔と称する。
sen.e: More strictly, tahoto had to have three pillars between the vertexes of the square, which means that each side had four pillars and four spaces between them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）日本語でも理解するのに少々時間がかかりました。「方三間」があくまでも理解しにくいのですが、「1辺に柱が4本立ち柱間が4間あるの意」ことから想像して、四角形の床の頂点の間に、三本の柱を立てると、一辺の柱間が４間とれ、頂点にも当然柱が立っているため、一辺には、それぞれ４本の柱が立つことになり、ほぼ、ここの意味が理解できるものと思われました。
sen.e: More specifically, a tahoto had to have three pillars between the vertices of the square, which means that each side had four pillars with four spaces between them.
More specifically, a tahoto had to have three pillars between the vertices of the square, which means that each side had four pillars with four spaces between them.

sen.j: 方五間のものを「大塔」と称する。
sen.e: The one that has five spaces on one side of the square is called "Daito" (literally, "large pagoda").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （3）
sen.e: The one that has five spaces on one side of the square is called "Daito" (literally, "large pagoda").
The one that has five spaces on one side of the square is called 'Daito' (literally, "large pagoda").

sen.j: 天台系には初重・二重とも平面方形の二重塔があるがこれは単に「二重塔」と呼称している。
sen.e: The temples of the Tendai sect have built pagodas with the floors on both the first and second levels in the shape of a square, and they simply call them "two-story pagoda".
The temples of the Tendai sect have built pagodas with the floors on both the first and second levels in the shape of a square, and they simply call them "two-story pagodas."
The temples of the Tendai sect have built pagodas with the floors on both the first and second levels in the shape of a square, and they simply call them 'two-story pagodas.'

sen.j: 多宝塔の初重内部は須弥壇を設け、仏像を安置するのが原則である。
sen.e: In a tahoto, a shumidan (an altar in the shape of Mt. Shumi) is usually placed on the first floor and Buddhist statues are installed on it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）
sen.e: In a tahoto, a shumidan (an altar in the shape of Mt. Shumi) is usually placed on the first floor and Buddhist statues are installed on it.
In a tahoto, a shumidan (an altar in the shape of Mt. Shumi) is usually placed on the first floor and Buddhist statues are installed on it.

sen.j: 石山寺多宝塔のように大日如来を本尊として安置する例が多い。
sen.e: As shown Ishiyama-dera Temple, Dainichi Nyorai is typically enshrined in tahoto as the principal image.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: As shown by Ishiyama-dera Temple, Dainichi Nyorai is typically enshrined in a tahoto as the principal image.
As shown by Ishiyama-dera Temple, Dainichi Nyorai is typically enshrined in a tahoto as the principal image.

sen.j: 「宝塔」は歴史的用語としては「塔」の美称であり、特定の建築形式を指すものではない。
sen.e: Historically, the term, "hoto" has been used to refer to pagodas eulogistically, but it does not specify a certain architectural style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）
sen.e: Historically, the term "hoto" has been used in reference to pagodas eulogistically, but it doesn't specify a certain architectural style.
Historically, the term 'hoto' has been used in reference to pagodas eulogistically, but it doesn't specify a certain architectural style.

sen.j: 現代の寺院建築用語では、円筒形の塔身に宝形造（四角錐形）の屋根を載せた形の塔を「宝塔」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: However, today's temple architects define "hoto" as pagodas with the cylinder-shaped body topped by a roof in the shape of a four-sided pyramid.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: However, today's temple architects define a "hoto" as a pagoda with a cylinder-shaped body topped by a roof in the shape of a four-sided pyramid.
However, today's temple architects define a 'hoto' as a pagoda with a cylinder-shaped body topped by a roof in the shape of a four-sided pyramid.

sen.j: この形式の「宝塔」は徳川将軍家の霊廟などにも用いられる。
sen.e: Hoto of this style were often used for the mausoleums of the Tokugawa shogunate.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）
sen.e: Hoto of this style were often used for the mausoleums of the Tokugawa shogunate.
Hoto of this style were often used for the mausoleums of the Tokugawa shogunate.

sen.j: 銅製や石造のものをしばしば見るが、木造の塔でこの形式のものは少ない。
sen.e: They were usually made of copper or stone; few were made of wood.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: They were usually made of copper or stone; few were made of wood.
They were usually made of copper or stone; few were made of wood.

sen.j: このような平面円形の「宝塔」形式の塔に庇を設けたものが多宝塔の原型とされている。
sen.e: Hoto with cylinder bodies and extended roofs are considered to be the archetype of tahoto.
Hoto with cylinder-shaped bodies and extended roofs are considered to be the archetypes of tahoto.
Hoto with cylinder-shaped bodies and extended roofs are considered to be the archetypes of tahoto.

sen.j: 多宝塔では初重と二重の間に「亀腹」と称する漆喰塗りの円形部分があり、円筒形の塔身の名残りを見せている。
sen.e: Between the first and second levels, the tahoto shows the cylinder-shaped body covered with white plaster; this part is called "Kamebara" (literally, "tortoise body") and indicative of a cylinder-shaped body it used to have.

Between the first and second levels, the tahoto shows a cylinder-shaped body covered in white plaster; this part is called "Kamebara" (literally, "tortoise body") and is indicative of the cylinder-shaped body it used to have.

Between the first and second levels, the tahoto shows a cylinder-shaped body covered in white plaster; this part is called 'Kamebara' (literally, "tortoise body") and is indicative of the cylinder-shaped body it used to have.

sen.j: ただし、円筒形に見えるのは外観のみで、構造的には四角い初重の上に平面円形の上層部を乗せたものである。
sen.e: Although the body of the pagoda appears to be in the shape of a cylinder, a tahoto is basically a cube topped by a cylinder-shaped structure.
Although the body of the pagoda appears to be in the shape of a cylinder, a tahoto is basically a cube topped by a cylinder-shaped structure.
Although the body of the pagoda appears to be in the shape of a cylinder, a tahoto is basically a cube topped by a cylinder-shaped structure.

sen.j: 法華宗･日蓮宗において、宝塔を本尊として用いる。
sen.e: The temples of the Hokke and Nichiren sects worship hoto as their principle image.
The temples of the Hokke and Nichiren sects worship hoto as their principle image.
The temples of the Hokke and Nichiren sects worship hoto as their principle image.

sen.j: 塔の両脇に釈迦牟尼仏と多宝如来を安置した、「一塔両尊」の形式の本尊である。
sen.e: They have adopted a style called "Itto ryozon" (literally, "a pagoda and two Buddha") where a pagoda is placed between Shakamuni-butsu and Taho Nyorai.
They have adopted a style called "Itto ryozon" (literally, "a pagoda and two Buddha") where a pagoda is placed between Shakamuni-butsu and Taho Nyorai.
They have adopted a style called 'Itto ryozon' (literally, "a pagoda and two Buddha") where a pagoda is placed between Shakamuni-butsu and Taho Nyorai.

sen.j: 四菩薩日蓮宗・法華宗における四菩薩を従えた「一塔両尊四士」の形式をとることも有る。
sen.e: This style may sometimes take a form called "Itto ryozon shishi", where four Bosatsu (bodhisattva) worshipped by the sects are added to the above "Itto ryozon".
sen.cmt: 「四菩薩日蓮宗」として始まっていますが、誤植十も和得れます。頭の「四菩薩」を省いた形で訳させていただきます。「日蓮宗・法華宗における」という表記が出てきますが、ここでは、日蓮宗・法華宗における内容が述べられていることは明白なので、繰り返しを意味もあり、「the sects」として表現しています。
sen.e: This style may sometimes take a form called "Itto ryozon shishi," where four Bosatsu (bodhisattva) worshipped by the sects are added to the above "Itto ryozon."
This style may sometimes take a form called 'Itto ryozon shishi,' where four Bosatsu (bodhisattva) worshipped by the sects are added to the above 'Itto ryozon.'

tit.e: How the tahoto style came into existence

sen.j: 初重を平面方形、二重を平面円形とする二層塔は日本独自の形式である。
sen.e: Two-story pagodas with the square floor on the first level and the round floor on the second level were invented and uniquely developed in Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）
sen.e: The two-story pagoda with a squared floor on the first level and a circular floor on the second level was invented and uniquely developed in Japan.
The two-story pagoda with a squared floor on the first level and a circular floor on the second level was invented and uniquely developed in Japan.

sen.j: 空海が高野山に建立を計画していた毘盧遮那法界体性塔（びるしゃなほっかいたいしょうとう）にその原型が求められる。
sen.e: The origin of this style is found in Birushana hokkai taisho, a pagoda that Kukai (one of the best known and most beloved Buddhist saints in Japan, founder of the Shingon ("True Word") school of Buddhism) planned to build in Mt. Koya.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: The origin of this style is found in Birushana hokkai taisho, a pagoda that Kukai (one of Japan's best known, most beloved Buddhist saints, and founder of the Shingon ("True Word") school of Buddhism) planned to build at Mt. Koya.

The origin of this style is found in Birushana hokkai taisho, a pagoda that Kukai (one of Japan's best known, most beloved Buddhist saints, and founder of the Shingon ("True Word") school of Buddhism) planned to build at Mt. Koya.

sen.j: この塔は空海の没後に完成し、その後も何回か焼失した。
sen.e: The pagoda, once completed after he died, was destroyed many times by fires.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （1）
sen.e: The pagoda, which was completed after he died, was subsequently destroyed many times by fires.
The pagoda, which was completed after he died, was subsequently destroyed many times by fires.

sen.j: 現在高野山にある塔は昭和12年（1938年）に再建された鉄筋コンクリート造のものである。
sen.e: The pagoda now found in Mt. Koya is the one rebuilt with reinforced concrete in 1938.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （2）
sen.e: The pagoda now found in Mt. Koya is the one rebuilt with reinforced concrete in 1938.
The pagoda now found in Mt. Koya is the one rebuilt with reinforced concrete in 1938.

sen.j: （大塔または根本大塔と呼ばれる）
sen.e: (This pagoda is called "Daito" (literally, "large pagoda") or "Konpon Daito" ("large pagoda, the root of the universe")).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理 （3）(大塔または根本大塔と呼ばれる)の挿入部分が読みにくくなるため、分離させました。
sen.e: (This pagoda is called "Daito" (literally, "large pagoda") or "Konpon Daito" ("large pagoda, the root of the universe").
(This pagoda is called "Daito" (literally, "large pagoda") or "Konpon Daito" ("large pagoda, the root of the universe")).

sen.j: この塔の創建時の形態は、現在の多宝塔に近いものであったと考証されている。
sen.e: Evidence shows that the pagoda initially built was close to what we see today.
Evidence shows that the pagoda initially built was close to what we see today.
Evidence shows that the pagoda initially built was close to what we see today.

sen.j: 空海とともに平安時代初期の仏教界で活動した最澄は法華経千部を安置する塔を日本各地の6か所に建立することを計画した。
sen.e: Saicho, who is considered one of the most active Buddhist priests in the early Heian period along with Kukai, also planned to build six pagodas in various parts of Japan to store 1000 copies of the Lotus Sutra.

Saicho, who is considered to have been one of the most active Buddhist priests in the early Heian period along with Kukai, also planned to build six pagodas in various parts of Japan in order to house 1000 copies of the Lotus Sutra.

Saicho, who is considered to have been one of the most active Buddhist priests in the early Heian period along with Kukai, also planned to build six pagodas in various parts of Japan in order to house 1000 copies of the Lotus Sutra.

sen.j: これは現在で言う多宝塔とは異なり、初重・二重ともに平面方形の二重塔であった。
sen.e: However, unlike today's tahoto, they were two-story pagodas that had square floors on both the first and second levels.
However, unlike today's tahoto, they were two-story pagodas that had squared floors on both the first and second levels.
However, unlike today's tahoto, they were two-story pagodas that had squared floors on both the first and second levels.

sen.j: 現在、比叡山延暦寺にある法華総持院東塔は1980年に建立されたものだが、初重・二重とも方形の形式を保っている。
sen.e: "Hokke Soji-in Toto", a pagoda built in Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hie in 1980 to control the six pagodas built by Saicho, still maintains its original style: square floors on both the first and second levels.

"Hokke Soji-in Toto," a pagoda built at Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hie in 1980 to control the six pagodas built by Saicho, still maintains its original style with squared floors on both the first and second levels.

Hokke Soji-in Toto, a pagoda built at Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hie in 1980 to control the six pagodas built by Saicho, still maintains its original style with squared floors on both the first and second levels.

sen.j: この形式の二重塔で近世以前にさかのぼるものはきわめて少なく、徳島県の切幡寺塔婆はその貴重な遺例である。
sen.e: Two-story pagodas of this style were extremely few in number before pre-modern times; the one in Kirihata-ji Temple in Tokushima Prefecture may be a rare example.
There were very few two-story pagodas of this style before pre-modern times; the one at Kirihata-ji Temple in Tokushima Prefecture may be a rare example.
There were very few two-story pagodas of this style before pre-modern times; the one at Kirihata-ji Temple in Tokushima Prefecture may be a rare example.

sen.j: この切幡寺塔は、もとは大阪の住吉大社の神宮寺にあり、元和4年（1618年）に建てられたものだが、明治時代初期に現在地に移建されている。
sen.e: This tower was initially built within the precinct of Jingu-ji Temple associated with Sumiyoshi-taish Shrine in Osaka in 1618, and moved to where it now stands in the early Meiji period.

This tower was initially built in 1618 within the precinct of Jingu-ji Temple, which was associated with Sumiyoshi-taish Shrine in Osaka, but early in the Meiji period it was moved to where it now stands.

This tower was initially built in 1618 within the precinct of Jingu-ji Temple, which was associated with Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine in Osaka, but early in the Meiji period it was moved to where it now stands.
